content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

Orthodontists use Temporary Anchoring Devices <math alttext="(T A D s)" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>TADs</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to keep teeth in place. <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> can be made of stainless steel or titanium. A certain amount of damage is expected during use of the <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math>, but too much damage to the <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> could result in a failure to achieve the desired results. An experiment was performed to compare the mean amount of damage to <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> made of stainless steel to the mean amount of damage to <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> made of titanium. Researchers recruited <math alttext="386" overflow="scroll"><mn>386</mn></math> volunteer orthodontic patients requiring <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> to participate in the experiment. Each volunteer had a <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of stainless steel placed on one side of the mouth and a <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of titanium placed on the other side of the mouth. For each volunteer, a flip of a fair coin determined which side of the mouth, left (Heads) or right (Tails), received the <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of stainless steel. The other side of the mouth received the <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of titanium. After six months, an orthodontist recorded the amount of damage observed on each <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> on a scale of <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math>, with <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> representing the least damage and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> representing the most damage.

(a) Identify the experimental units and treatments in the context of this experiment.

Experimental units

Treatments

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

Orthodontists use Temporary Anchoring Devices <math alttext="(T A D s)" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>TADs</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to keep teeth in place. <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> can be made of stainless steel or titanium. A certain amount of damage is expected during use of the <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math>, but too much damage to the <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> could result in a failure to achieve the desired results. An experiment was performed to compare the mean amount of damage to <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> made of stainless steel to the mean amount of damage to <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> made of titanium. Researchers recruited <math alttext="386" overflow="scroll"><mn>386</mn></math> volunteer orthodontic patients requiring <math alttext="T A D s" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math> to participate in the experiment. Each volunteer had a <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of stainless steel placed on one side of the mouth and a <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of titanium placed on the other side of the mouth. For each volunteer, a flip of a fair coin determined which side of the mouth, left (Heads) or right (Tails), received the <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of stainless steel. The other side of the mouth received the <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> made of titanium. After six months, an orthodontist recorded the amount of damage observed on each <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math> on a scale of <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math>, with <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> representing the least damage and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> representing the most damage.

(a) Identify the experimental units and treatments in the context of this experiment.

Experimental units

Treatments

(b) Consider the design of this experiment.
(i) Identify the experimental design.

(ii) Characteristics of each volunteer, such as age, diet, and dental hygiene, influence the amount of damage to a <math alttext="T A D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TAD</mtext></math>. Explain how the design of this experiment controls for the effects of these characteristics.
(c) What would it mean for this experiment to be single-blind?

(d) Suppose the experiment showed no significant difference in the mean amount of damage between the two types of <math alttext="T A D s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADs</mtext></math>. Can these results be generalized to all orthodontic patients requiring <math alttext="T A D s?" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>TADsâ€Š?</mtext></math> Justify your response.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
